newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai Airways not keen on leasing planes.
newsitem.headline: Thai Airways not keen on leasing planes.

text.p: Thai Airways International Plc may not be able to meet the government's request to delay a fleet expansion and instead lease aircraft, company officials said on Tuesday.

Phisit Kuslasayanond, Thai Airways executive vice-president, told reporters the airline would attempt to abide by the government request but new aircraft needed for service may not be available for leasing.

"In leasing aircraft, we have to see if Thai Airways can find the types of planes that it requires, and sometimes we just cannot do that. In the end, we may end up buying them anyway. Other alternatives may be just stop-gap measures," he said.

Chairman Mahidol Chantrangkul said the board of the airline, 93 owned percent by the government, will meet next week to consider the request to delay a plan to order 21 new planes in the 1996-2000 period.
Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh and Finance Minister Amnuay Viravan said on Monday Thai Airways should consider leasing aircraft to meet its expansion needs.
They said the move could save the country precious foreign exchange and help narrow its current account deficit which stood at 8.2 percent of gross domestic product in 1996.
Thai Airways has budgetted 68.79 billion baht for buying 21 aircraft over a five-year period ending September 30, 2000.
The new aircrafts that Thai Airways plans to order include six Boeing 777-300s, five Airbus 300-600s, four Boeing 737-400/500s, four Airbus 330-300s and two Boeing 747-400s.
